intro: Tryphia parviflora, commonly known as the small-flowered tryphia, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. It has a compact growth habit and is often found in clusters, with its foliage resembling that of a fern. Due to its delicate appearance and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species in many areas.
